cells.data:
If there’s an pre-existing starting point: 

  1. Fork the workshop starting point on Github
  2. Clone your fork onto your own machine: ​git clone​ ​URL-TO-YOUR-FORK-HERE​
  3. Add to your partner’s fork as a remote called “partner”: ​git remote add partner URL-TO-PARTNER-FORK-HERE​
  4. To check if you’ve successfully added “partner”, list all the remotes associated with your local repo: ​git remote -v​
  5. If you made a mistake adding “partner”, you can always remove it and then try step 3 again: ​git remote rm partner 

​​If there’s no starting point: 

  1. Make a directory for the workshop on your computer: ​mkdir WORKSHOP-NAME-HERE​
  2. Create a local git repo in that directory: ​cd WORKSHOP-NAME-HERE && git init​
  3. Make a new repo on GitHub
  4. Add your new GitHub repo as a remote for your local repo: ​git remote add origin URL-TO-YOUR-FORK-HERE​
  5. Add your partner’s fork as a remote called “partner”: ​git remote add partner URL-TO-PARTNER-FORK-HERE

​​When it’s your turn to drive on your machine:

  1. Get your partner’s work: ​git pull partner master
  2. ​​Stage your changes: ​git add -A ​
  3. Commit your work: ​git commit -m “commit message here”
  4. ​​​Push your work up to your remote repo: ​git push origin master
